Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Direct Detection of MeV-Scale Dark Matter Utilizing Germanium Internal Amplification for the Charge Created by the Ionization of Impurities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known elementary particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter (DM) is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. One of the most exciting quests is the search for new particles beyond the Standard Model of Particle Physics, which describes all the known elementary particles and the interactions between them. Extensions of the model predict not only new particles with large masses but also some with very small masses. The general properties of neutrinos and the nature of DM are currently two of the most important questions in fundamental physics. This EAGER award will explore a new germanium (Ge) detector technology utilizing Charge Internal Amplification (GeCIA) for the charge carriers created by the ionization of impurities, which is a promising new technology with experimental sensitivity for detecting MeV-scale dark matter.

Novel direct-detection strategies to probe non-gravitational interactions between DM and ordinary matter are needed to discover DM. The broad resources gained through this exploratory work will enable the development of next generation detectors that meet sensitivity requirements in a cost-effective manner. The techniques developed will have immediate application to several experiments, including the DM program and low energy neutrino program in the U.S. and elsewhere in the world. Equally important and central to the planned activities is its work to develop the next generation of diverse workers. One female postdoc will fully work on the project and become expertise in developing GeCIA detectors. In addition, three PhD students will also work on the project.

GeCIA will adopt a phased approach to build an experiment at Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) to directly search for DM with a mass range from 0.1 MeV to 1 GeV. GeCIA-0 is an exploratory project that will innovate GeCIA detectors at a mass of 300 grams to demonstrate the technology for a p-type planar geometry. They will fabricate a planar detector with amorphous Ge (a-Ge) contact technology, which has been successfully used to fabricate detectors at USD with home-grown crystals. This funding will support the group to (1) optimize the design of such a planar detector with Monte Carlo simulation; (2) fabricate a planar detector with a-Ge contact technology; (3) prove GeCIA technology with appropriate electronic read-out system; and (4) calibrate detectors with optical and low energy radiative sources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Germanium (Ge) Internal Charge Amplification (GeICA) is a promising technology in the search for low-mass (~MeV-Scale) dark matter (DM). When it is innovated, GeICA will amplify the charge carriers induced by the MeV-scale DM interacting with Ge atoms through emission of phonons. It is those phonons that will create charge carriers through the ionization of impurities to achieve an extremely low energy threshold of < 0.1 eV. Specifically, the goal of this award is to study the flexibility in developing GeICA detectors with an amplification factor of ~10 ? 100 to prove the technology. Utilizing USD-grown crystals, the key work is to conduct R&D activities to find a suitable electrical breakdown prevention structure for novel Ge detectors with internal charge amplification similar to multi-wire proportional counters, which amplifies charge carriers as a function of bias voltage. To effectively carry out the proposed activities, we leveraged the existing facilities and equipment at the University of South Dakota (USD). Finally, we trained a diverse workforce (undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs) to lead research and development (R&D) activities on MeV-scale DM searches.

During the period of the EAGER award, we have already built and tested six p-type small miniPPC detectors (~20 grams) with a guard-ring structure. The geometry of the point contact detectors is shown in Figure 1. The size of the point contact is about 1 mm2. We summarize what we have achieved from this EAGER award below: 

(i) The fabrication of planar detectors with a-Ge contacts. We have successfully fabricated ten planar detectors with a-Ge contacts using the USD-grown crystals. The fabrication process and the characterization of the detectors are described in detail in a recent paper (arXiv:2002.04462). Figure 2 shows the energy spectrum of a planar detector that we fabricated in our lab. Six out of ten were made into PPC detectors.

(ii) Investigation of a-Ge contact properties. We have reported the contact properties of a-Ge for the energy barrier height, the barrier lowering term, and the density of localized energy states near the Fermi level in the a-Ge contacts in a recent paper (arXiv:2002.04462). The leakage current has been measured to be at the level of ~pA at 79 K for planar detectors prior to making into PPC detectors, as shown in Figure 1. Six PPC detectors were tested. 

(iii) Observation of avalanche phenomenon in the lab. With the size of the point contact being about ~1 mm2, we have observed the charge current flow as described in Figure 3. In the drift region (< 2300 volts), the charge carriers are drifted by the electric field without internal charge amplification. Between 2300 to 2700 volts, the multiplication of charge carriers is proportional to the applied bias voltage. Beyond 2700 volts, the total current approaches a plateau region until <2900 volts at which the total current showing a constant output (avalanche breakdown or Geiger mode). Soon after 2900 V, the total current became unstable. (iv) Tests with multiple detectors. Four PPC detectors run into electrical breakdown < 3000 volts, which corresponds to a E-field of >104 V/cm, due to a high surface leakage current. Two survived 3000 volts through many tests at 77 K. Since the surface thermal emission rate is still high at 77 K, we leveraged a collaborator?s cryogenic testing facility at University of Minnesota and tested a detector at 0.04 K.
